title.narrative: SWE-2010-150 Management of pea bruchid by application of host plant resistance tactics and integrated pest management strategies in partnership with f
SWE-2010-150 Management of pea bruchid by application of host plant resistance tactics and integrated pest management strategies in partnership with f

description.narrative: The majority of rural and urban dwellers in Ethiopia rely on pulses as their main source of protein. Apart from securing food, pulses increase soil fertility and provide a valuable break crop after cereals. About 9.7 million households are engaged in pulse production. The emphasis of the Ethiopian Government on market-oriented production of legumes opens an opportunity for increased incomes. However, productivity is low mainly due to insect pests. Focusing on field pea, and its most destructive pest, pea bruchid, the project aims at increasing production of pulses in Ethiopia through developing resistant field pea varieties and integrated biological controls. The outcomes of the project will be applied through participatory field implementation and capacity building in partnership with farmers and extension agents. The project will enforce unique scientific infrastructures at AAU.

The majority of rural and urban dwellers in Ethiopia rely on pulses as their main source of protein. Apart from securing food, pulses increase soil fertility and provide a valuable break crop after cereals. About 9.7 million households are engaged in pulse production. The emphasis of the Ethiopian Government on market-oriented production of legumes opens an opportunity for increased incomes. However, productivity is low mainly due to insect pests. Focusing on field pea, and its most destructive pest, pea bruchid, the project aims at increasing production of pulses in Ethiopia through developing resistant field pea varieties and integrated biological controls. The outcomes of the project will be applied through participatory field implementation and capacity building in partnership with farmers and extension agents. The project will enforce unique scientific infrastructures at AAU.
